concepts.concept_name: Types of synthetic fibres: rayon, nylon, polyester, acrylic
Characteristics and uses of synthetic fibres

in_scope: Natural fibres vs synthetic fibres
Polymers: definition and examples
Rayon: artificial silk, made from wood pulp
Nylon: first fully synthetic fibre, strong and elastic
Polyester: wrinkle-resistant, used in clothing (PET)
Acrylic: wool substitute, lightweight and warm
Properties of synthetic fibres: strong, durable, wrinkle-resistant, quick-drying
Plastics: polymers that can be moulded
Thermoplastics: can be remoulded on heating (PVC, polythene)
Thermosetting plastics: cannot be remoulded (bakelite, melamine)
Biodegradable vs non-biodegradable waste
Environmental impact of plastics: 4R principle (Reduce, Reuse, Recycle, Recover)
out_of_scope: Polymerisation reactions and mechanisms — Introduced in Class 10
Molecular structures of polymers — Introduced in Class 10
Industrial manufacturing processes — Introduced in Class 11

concepts.concept_name: Physical properties of metals and non-metals

in_scope: Physical properties of metals: lustre, malleability, ductility, conductivity, sonority
Physical properties of non-metals: brittle, non-lustrous, poor conductors
Exceptions: mercury is liquid metal, iodine is lustrous non-metal
Reaction of metals with oxygen: formation of metal oxides (basic)
Reaction of metals with water
Reaction of metals with acids: hydrogen gas evolved
Reaction of metals with salt solutions: displacement reactions
Non-metals react with oxygen to form acidic or neutral oxides
Reactivity series: order of reactivity of common metals
Displacement reaction: more reactive metal displaces less reactive
Uses of metals: iron for construction, copper for wiring, aluminium for utensils
Uses of non-metals: oxygen for respiration, nitrogen for fertilisers
out_of_scope: Ionic and covalent bonding — Introduced in Class 9
Extraction of metals from ores — Introduced in Class 10

in_scope: Exhaustible resources: coal, petroleum, natural gas (fossil fuels)
Inexhaustible resources: sunlight, wind, water
Coal formation: carbonisation of dead vegetation over millions of years
Types of coal: peat, lignite, bituminous, anthracite
Products of coal: coke, coal tar, coal gas
Coke: used in steel making and extraction of metals
Coal tar: source of dyes, drugs, perfumes, plastics, paints
Petroleum: formation from dead marine organisms under pressure
Refining of petroleum: fractional distillation
Petroleum fractions: LPG, petrol, diesel, kerosene, lubricating oil, paraffin wax, bitumen
Natural gas: CNG as clean fuel
Petrochemicals: products derived from petroleum
Conservation of fossil fuels and PCRA guidelines
out_of_scope: Detailed organic chemistry of hydrocarbons — Introduced in Class 10
Fractional distillation apparatus details — Introduced in Class 10
Carbon cycle in detail — Introduced in Class 9

concepts.concept_name: Structure and zones of a flame

in_scope: Combustion: burning of a substance in the presence of oxygen
Conditions for combustion: fuel, oxygen (air), ignition temperature
Types of combustion: rapid, spontaneous, explosion
Ignition temperature: minimum temperature to catch fire
Inflammable substances: low ignition temperature (petrol, alcohol, LPG)
Fire triangle: fuel, heat, oxygen
Fire extinguisher: principle of cutting off fuel, heat, or oxygen
Structure of a candle flame: three zones
Dark zone (innermost): unburnt wax vapour, least hot
Luminous zone (middle): partial combustion, yellow, moderately hot
Non-luminous zone (outermost): complete combustion, blue, hottest
Calorific value: heat produced per unit mass of fuel (kJ/kg)
Comparison of calorific values of common fuels
Ideal fuel characteristics: high calorific value, less pollution
out_of_scope: Chemical equations for combustion — Introduced in Class 10
Enthalpy and thermochemistry — Introduced in Class 11
Detailed fire safety engineering — Not in syllabus

concepts.concept_name: Effects of air pollution and control measures

in_scope: Air pollutants: carbon monoxide, carbon dioxide, sulphur dioxide, nitrogen oxides, particulate matter, CFCs
Sources: vehicles, factories, power plants, burning of fossil fuels and waste
Acid rain: formation from SO2 and NO2, effects on monuments and aquatic life
Global warming: greenhouse effect, CO2 increase
Ozone layer depletion: role of CFCs
Smog: smoke + fog, health effects
Taj Mahal: marble cancer due to acid rain
Control measures: use of CNG, unleaded petrol, catalytic converters
Water pollutants: sewage, industrial waste, pesticides, fertilisers
Eutrophication: excessive nutrients leading to algal bloom
Potable water: safe for drinking
Water purification methods: filtration, chlorination, boiling, RO
Ganga Action Plan and water conservation
Three Rs: Reduce, Reuse, Recycle
out_of_scope: Detailed atmospheric chemistry — Introduced in Class 10
BOD and COD calculations — Introduced in Class 11
Water treatment plant design — Not in syllabus
